e4: The CFO has significant concerns that replacing the existing policy with a new one could hurt retail investors and lead to them being traded against by hedge funds. He also notes that there would be no way for his investment relations team to communicate the change, potentially resulting in investor disappointment when they don't receive their typical upward earnings adjustments.
e5: An ethical reporting policy would prioritize transparency, accuracy, and fairness. Ideally, it should not introduce biases or complexities that favor certain groups over others. In a context where retail investors may rely on certain expectations, any changes to the reporting policy should take their potential interests into account and provide clarity in its new form. Moreover, consideration of how different stakeholders (e.g., retail, institutional, individual) might be affected by specific policies would also be desirable, to minimize unintended harm or unfair advantage.
e6: Yes. Potential follow-up questions could include the likelihood and feasibility of the change back to the original earnings bias being implemented in future reporting, whether there have been previous discussions among investors about potential implications of losing that upward revenue surprise in case no adjustment is made in reported revenues from biased policies implemented under former corporate leadership's time at ABC management , as well as discussion regarding any alternatives strategies with similar results as adjusting EPS before adopting final revised policy if this decision be implemented later on later this fiscal quarter after careful review.
